title: 105_hr2186
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds that the City of Casper, Wyoming, is significant for the convergence of multiple historic trails, representing themes of migration, settlement, transportation, and commerce in the West. The Bureau of Land Management has yet to establish a historic trails interpretive center in Wyoming or adjacent states. The City of Casper, Wyoming, in collaboration with the National Historic Trails Foundation, established a National Historic Trails Interpretive Center to educate the public on mid-19th-century immigrant trails in the Intermountain West. This initiative is in line with the National Trails System Act's objectives. The State of Wyoming and the City of Casper have contributed funds to establish the National Historic Trails Interpretive Center, with support from the National Historic Trails Foundation. The Bureau of Land Management has completed the engineering and design phase for the project. The National Historic Trails Interpretive Center in Casper, Wyoming is ready for Federal assistance to construct the center. The Act aims to recognize the historic trails in the area, assist in establishing the center, and showcase the Bureau of Land Management's stewardship of public lands. The National Historic Trails Interpretive Center in Casper, Wyoming is ready for Federal assistance to construct the center. The Act aims to recognize the historic trails in the area and showcase the Bureau of Land Management's stewardship of public lands. The Secretary of the Interior will establish the National Historic Trails Interpretive Center in Casper, Wyoming, to interpret historic trails like the Oregon Trail and the Pony Express Trail. The Center will be constructed in cooperation with the City of Casper and the National Historic Trails Interpretive Center Foundation, Inc. The National Historic Trails Interpretive Center in Casper, Wyoming, will be established in cooperation with the City of Casper and the Historic Trails Interpretive Center Foundation, Inc. The Secretary of the Interior may accept donations for the development and operation of the Center and may also charge entrance fees. The Conservation Fund Act of 1965 allows the Secretary to collect entrance fees from visitors to the National Historic Trails Interpretive Center in Casper, Wyoming, and use the funds for operating expenses. $5,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary to carry out this section. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
